segments.text: To model this in the DP, when considering adding a flight to the path, for each city i, the new distance would be the minimum over all j of (current distance to j with k-1 flights + (i-j)^2). To compute this efficiently, the DP can be represented as a linear function. Let's think of dp[i][f] as the minimal time to reach city i with exactly f flights. Then, when we want to compute dp[i][f], it's the minimum over all j of (dp[j][f-1] + (i-j)^2). This expression can be rewritten as (i² - 2ij + j²) + dp[j][f-1]. So, grouping terms by j, this becomes ( -2i * j ) + (j² + dp[j][f-1]) + i². So, for each j, this is a linear function in terms of i: m_j * i + b_j, where m_j is -2j, and b_j is j² + dp[j][f-1]. The minimal value over all j for a given i would be the minimum of these lines evaluated at i. The convex hull trick is used here to maintain these lines and query the minimal value efficiently.
